docs.text: capsule : the director of cure brings a weird and very complex concept to the screen .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: one viewing will not be enough to understand fully the premise of pulse .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the idea is something about ghosts and the internet .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the film has an amazing apocalyptic style .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: perhaps the most disturbing ( and disturbed ? )
docs.label: positive

docs.text: filmmaker in the world is kiyoshi kurosawa .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his films all seem to have one style , bleak .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the worlds he creates are terrifying and cold .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: little known in the us to date , his films deliver the kind of horror that so many of our filmmakers promise and are unable to deliver .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: most of his ideas are fresh and at the same time morbid .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his 1998 film cure , with one of his niftiest ideas , is just now getting a sadly limited release in the us and hopefully enough people will see it that his name will soon be one to conjure with .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: cure is probably his classic .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: last year he released seance , a remake of seance on a wet afternoon .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: that was perhaps a miscalculation inserting supernatural elements into a non-supernatural story .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: pulse is kurosawa back on form .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: taguchi , a young computer expert , is late with his delivery of some important software .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: two co-workers go to his apartment and find it a dismal dark affair in spite of his computer equipment .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: taguchi , acting very strangely , lets his friends look for the missing software .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: meanwhile he slips behind a plastic curtain .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: when he fails to respond to calls his friends follow him behind the curtain and discover he has hanged himself .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if that was not horror enough the body seems to disappear leaving just a strange dark mildew-like spot on the wall .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: taguchi's computer seems to have been infected with some kind of computer virus .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: people whose computer gets the virus seem superficially to die via suicide .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: but they are not entirely dead .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: their spirits seem to remain present somehow in the real world and on the internet .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: people who get the computer virus are asked if they want to see a ghost .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: if they say yes , they seem to be able to see real time images of the spirits still nearby somehow .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: the computer shows them impossible images of ghosts in their own rooms as seen from cameras that do not exist .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is all somehow connected to heaven and hell somehow filling up and overflowing " like a computer disk . "
docs.label: positive

docs.text: instead the dead seem to be staying on earth and inhabiting computer viruses .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: there is some sort of passage between worlds having something to do with doors marked with red tape and strange electronic disturbances on computers .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: leave it to kurosawa to find a new kind of death .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: this is a film that has more weird ideas piled together than lifeforce and somehow kurosawa makes the film all work .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: it may not totally convey his message of isolation and its parallels to death , but whatever it does convey is nightmarish .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: kurosawa , who directs his own screenplay , ties his story into the real world with some familiar and accurate computer discussion .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: frequently the plot is advanced with character hunches being assumed to be fact .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: his plotting is frequently hard to follow and always very strange .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: junichiro hayashi , the cinematographer who recently has been doing all of kurosawa's films , creates a dark , cold , and gloomy tone .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: images are obscured by semi-lighting or are behind plastic curtain .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: scenes are not milked for their horror the way american exploitation films might .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: people are shot with guns but there is little if any blood in evidence .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: seeing black silhouettes on computer screens is not immediately scary .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: kurosawa is not going for and easy visual shock , but a deeper metaphysical dread .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: of any horror filmmaker in the world , kiyoshi kurosawa is the one to watch .
docs.label: positive

docs.text: i rate this metaphysical look at isolation a 7 on the 0 to 10 scale and a +2 on the -4 to +4 scale .
docs.label: positive
